description: In Nicaragua, on April 21, 2020, Schools were ordered to stay open. Nicaragua ordered its more than 1.8 million students back to class Monday, in spite of concerns about spreading the novel coronavirus that have led other countries in the region to try to keep education on track through remote learning. Government education adviser Salvador Vanegas told the government website El 19 Monday that Health Ministry protocols about hand-washing hand been implemented.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with no conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 19th  Carolina Dávila, the minister advisor, informed through official media outlets that the Government of Daniel Ortega is involved in negotiations with pharmaceutical laboratories to buy more vaccines against covid-19 and reiterated the promise to immunize 70% of Nicaraguans during 2021.“We already have the funds to bring in the purchase, and what we are doing is to negotiate, to see the availability of the companies and get the vaccines. We would continue vaccinating according to age groups, as we are doing with people under 55 years,” Davila said.According to the “Covid-19 vaccine project”, presented by the Ministry of Health (Minsa) in January this year, the Government’s plan was to invest in the purchase of 7.4 million vaccines: 1.5 million being  Moderna
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: The Ministry of Health (Minsa) reached this Wednesday the eighth day of immunization against the coronavirus in older adults in Managua. The biological that is being applied free of charge by the Nicaraguan health governing institution is the second dose of the drug Covisiheld, imported from India. The centers where people over 60 years of age were vaccinated were the western Francisco Morazán health center and the Bertha Calderón, located on the eastern edge of the capital. They applied the second dose of the Covishield vaccine to those patients who received the first dose on April 13.

description:
The Nicaraguan Ministry of Health announced the 14th July 2020 that they will request to the travellers that want to entry to Nicaragua a negative result of the COVID-19 test, which must have be done before a maximum of 72 hours prior to the entry to the country.
In this regard, the Nicaraguan Ministry of Health declared the same day that non national travellers with symptoms of fever or respiratory symptons will not be allowed to entry to the country and that national travellers with fever or respiratory symptoms will be allowed to entry to the country but that they will be supervised at home.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
The Nicaraguan Institute of Civil Aviation (Nicaraguan government) announced the 14th July 2020 the beginning of the reopening of the International Airport Augusto C. Sandino and other details about the protocol that the airlines must fulfil (including also the health measures announced by the Nicaraguan Ministry of Health the same day-Resolution 346-2020 regarding the requirements that national and international travellers must comply with to entry to the country).
The airlines will have to present to the Nicaraguan Institute of Civil Aviation their plan to flight against the COVID-19 before restar their operations.
Moreover, it was announced that all the airlines will need to provide some information in order to operate  travellers, humanitarian or repatriation flights.
For instance, they will have to provide a fumigation certificate, a detailed list of travellers entring and exiting the country with a copy of their passports, an insurance certificate, medical certificate and crew licenses. All the information will have to be provided at least 72 hours before the flight operation date.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Rosario Murillo, the designated Nicaraguan vicepresident, announced the 22th July 2020 the entry of 100 Nicaraguan citizens the 21th July 2020 that were waiting to enter the country from Panamarian shelters due to the COVID-19 situation in the region. Also, she declared that more Nicaraguan citizens were waiting to entry the country in the coming days from Panana.The citizens that entered the country the 21th July had to pass a health check to rule out symptoms of COVID-19 and commit to be under quarantine 14 days at home.

description:
The Nicaraguan Ministry of Health announced the 14th July 2020 that they will request to the travellers that want to entry to Nicaragua a negative result of the COVID-19 test, which must have be done before a maximum of 72 hours prior to the entry to the country.
In this regard, the Nicaraguan Ministry of Health declared the same day that non national travellers with symptoms of fever or respiratory symptons will not be allowed to entry to the country and that national travellers with fever or respiratory symptoms will be allowed to entry to the country but that they will be supervised at home. UPDATE: The Nicaraguan Ministry of Health updated the Ministerial Resolution Number 346-2020 the 22th July 2020. The aim of this Resolution is to reinforce the epidemiological control of Nicaraguan nationals and travellers that want to entry the country through all the entry points. 
All the travellers will have to show a negative result of the PCR realized in real time to detect the COVID-19. This test must have be done in a period of time not higher than 72 hours before entring the country.
Moreover, if the travellers come from Asia, Africa or Oceania, the PCR which must show a negative result of the COVID-19 must have been done in a period of time not higher than 96 hours before entring the country. 
Non national travellers that want to entry the country with symptons of respiratory problems or flu will not be allowed to entry the country.
National travellers with symptons of respiratory problems or flu will be allowed to entry the country but will have to be under a mandatory quarantine at home.
Travellers that want to entry the country without flu or respiratory problems and a negative result of the PCR to detect the COVID-19 will have freedom of movement in the country but will be under health monitoring 14 days by health workers.
.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: The government has not officially announced any closures of its land and sea ports of entry or any significant restrictions on domestic movements and business operations. However, some sea vessels have been denied entry. Disruptions to travel at land, sea, and air ports of entry will likely persist despite the borders being opened. Heightened screening measures at the land borders could cause some delays to cargo transportation and other cross-border travel.

description: According to official figures, Nicaragua would only have 10 cases in total of COVID-19.For epidemiologists, it is not only difficult to understand but also how statistics presented by the Sandinista government work. The reason lies in the way Minsa and first lady and Vice President Rosario Murillo handle statistics. They exclude from the total of positive cases, patients who died or recovered from the virus.Experts in Nicaragua agree the government uses confusing arithmetic for propaganda purposes and to reinforce the idea that the health system has controlled the pandemic. The reduction of figures is not limited only to positive cases. Statistics are also applied to suspicious cases, so data is also always on the downside.Other experts added that in the absence of massive tests, Nicaragua suffers from “epidemiological blindness,” which could be serious in following the trail and curve of contagion of the virus.To date, the Ministry of Health has not revealed how many tests have been carried out in total. Due to pressure from independent experts for a larger sampling, Dr. Carlos Saenz was forced to give an answer. But it was a hesitation more than an exact number. “It can be around, I couldn't tell you at the moment, it was like ... more or less, 200. A hundred and something,” he said.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: According to the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) on June 3, 2020, the trace of the virus in Nicaragua has been completely lost within the country. The Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) described the situation of the coronavirus pandemic in Nicaragua as "very worrying" and "very difficult to control."This was determined by the director of PAHO Health Emergencies, Cito Ugarte, who has focused on the increase in the number of cases and deaths reported by official and unofficial sources in Nicaragua and on the situation of community transmission of the virus in the Central American country.“And when one loses track of the virus and one cannot prevent transmission from continuing, when there are social activities, it is necessary to immediately implement social distancing measures,” said Ugarte, who has insisted that physical distance is one of the “most important mechanisms to save lives and reduce transmission”.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

The Nicaraguan Ministry of Health announced the 3th July 2020 the receipt of the donation from the Indian government of their first load of medical assistance to fight against the COVID-19, consisting of 170.000 tablets of hydroxychloroquine. The second load of medical assistance from the Indian government was received the 10th July 2020, consisting of antibiotics, antipyretics and anti-parasite medication.

description:
National-Nicaragua. The Nicaraguan Ministry of Health announced the 6th July 2020 the strengthening of the intensive care units from the public hospitals with new equipment to fight against the COVID-19 and other diseases: ventilators with monitors, beds for hospitalisation, stretchers to transport patients and ultrasound devices.
It was said that 70 ventilators with monitors, 40 beds and 40 ultrasound devices will be send to the Nicaraguan public hospitals.
The Nicaraguan Ministry of Health indicated that this new equipment was bought with treasury funds.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: In Nicaragua, only the government can authorize tests for the coronavirus, but it has not said publicly how many have been done. While the government puts the COVID-19 infection tally at 16, the Observatorio Ciudadano, a civil society group, has kept a separate tally, estimating the number at 781. The group says it bases its estimate on information it receives from doctors and other groups, but declined to provide more detail.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Ministry of Health (Minsa) announced this Friday that it will charge US$150 for carrying out polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests that serve to identify the coronavirus. The test, available to Nicaraguans who must travel outside the country, will be carried out in the CNDR laboratory, which belongs to the State and operates in the “Conchita” Palacios Health Complex. In all of Central America, Nicaragua is the only country where Health authorities charge for carrying out the PCR tests to detect the spread of SARS CoV-2, despite the fact that, four months after the arrival of the pandemic, it does not report the number of tests carried out and their results.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Covid-19 tests are accessible through the Nicaraguan Ministry of Health, and it seems only for people who need them to exit the country. There is a testing fee of USD 150$, and it is necessary to have a flight boarding pass/itinerary. According to US Embassy, All testing in Nicaragua is carried out at the National Center for Diagnosis and Reference (CNDR) from 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m.  Test results are returned the same day between 4:00 p.m. and 5:00 p.m.Travelers wishing to be tested must present an identification card (cedula) or passport and their flight itinerary.  The $150 fee must be deposited in either Banpro account 10010012253774 (U.S. dollars) or 10010002253784 (cordobas), both registered under TGR-MINSA.  Cash payments can be made at Conchita Palacios National Health Complex.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Nicaraguan Ministry of Health announced the 17th July 2020 that they will realize the COVID-19 test to the people that are going to travel to other countries and that are being required a negative COVID--19 test to entry the country of destination. This test will have a cost of 150 USD and that will be only realized in the National Health Complex  
Dra. Concepción Palacios in Managua.
Interested people will mandatory have to provide their identification card or passport, the flight tickets or flight itinerary and the proof of payment in the specified bank account number.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: "Dr. Carlos Sáenz, Secretary General of the Ministry of Health, explained to the members of the Diplomatic Corps accredited in the country the different actions carried out by the Government through the Inter-institutional Commission to mitigate the possible effects of the coronavirus pandemic.  (...) Dr. Sáenz insisted on the importance of adopting preventive measures, which include:  - Develop the habit of frequent hand washing with soap and water for 20 seconds (...) - When coughing or sneezing, cover the nose and mouth (...). - The surface of frequently touched objects such as door handles, railings, tables or desks, telephones, toys, among others, should be cleaned (...)  - Family members with risk factors, such as older adults, people with diabetes, with cardiovascular diseases or with hypertension should be identified in order to take extreme measures to protect against respiratory diseases."
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Nicaraguan Authorities say they’re doing a responsible job preparing people for covid-19 — sending health teams door to door to encourage people to wash their hands and report fever or other virus symptoms. UPDATE: The original policy said that the government was sending health teams to do home visits. However, the government apparently also drafted public sector employees and party members to conduct in-person home visits across the country to inform people about the virus and recommend preventative measures such as hand-washing. As of June 5, the government claims that nearly 5.2 million home visits have been made.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
